title: Lesson 2: Functions and Temperature Conversion
description: Learn how to create and use functions in Python, with a focus on converting temperatures between Celsius and Fahrenheit.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In this lesson, you'll learn how to create and use functions in Python. Functions allow us to organize code into reusable blocks that perform specific tasks.

sections.title: Python Functions
sections.content: Functions are defined using the def keyword, followed by the function name and parentheses. Any parameters the function takes are placed inside the parentheses.

examples.title: Basic Function
examples.description: Here's a simple function that greets a person by name.
examples.code:
def greet(name):
    """This function greets the person passed in as a parameter"""
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

# Call the function
message = greet("Alice")
print(message)

# Call it again with a different name
print(greet("Bob"))

examples.title: Parameters and Return Values
examples.description: Functions can take input parameters and return values using the return statement.
examples.code:
def add_numbers(a, b):
    """This function adds two numbers and returns the result"""
    sum = a + b
    return sum

# Call the function and store the result
result = add_numbers(5, 3)
print(f"5 + 3 = {result}")

# We can use the function directly in expressions
print(f"10 + 20 = {add_numbers(10, 20)}")
print(f"Result × 2 = {add_numbers(5, 3) * 2}")

sections.title: Temperature Conversion
sections.content:
One common application of functions is to convert between different units of measurement. Let's look at how to convert between Celsius and Fahrenheit temperatures.

To convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit, use the formula: F = (C × 9/5) + 32

Where F is the temperature in Fahrenheit and C is the temperature in Celsius.

examples.title: Converting Celsius to Fahrenheit
examples.description: This function converts a temperature from Celsius to Fahrenheit using the formula F = (C × 9/5) + 32.
examples.code:
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    """Convert Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit"""
    fahrenheit = (celsius * 9/5) + 32
    return fahrenheit

# Test the function with some values
freezing_c = 0
freezing_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(freezing_c)
print(f"{freezing_c}°C is {freezing_f}°F")

body_temp_c = 37
body_temp_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(body_temp_c)
print(f"{body_temp_c}°C is {body_temp_f}°F")

boiling_c = 100
boiling_f = celsius_to_fahrenheit(boiling_c)
print(f"{boiling_c}°C is {boiling_f}°F")

sections.title: Understanding Testing
sections.content:
Testing is a crucial part of software development. When you click the "Test Solution" button, our system will run your function with various inputs and check if the outputs match the expected results.

The test cases include:
- Standard temperatures (freezing point, boiling point)
- Body temperature
- Negative temperatures
- Edge cases

Your function should handle all these cases correctly to pass the tests.
